The svg is a path with a defined stroke-dasharray.  The visual offset into the dash pattern is dependent on the stroke-width.

Basically:

<path ... stroke-width="1" stroke-dashoffset="4" ... />

is equivalent (in terms of dash offset) with

<path ... stroke-width="4" stroke-dashoffset="1" .../>

is equivalent (in terms of dash offset) with

<path ... stroke-width="2" stroke-dashoffset="2" .../>

Basically, the actual offset visually appears to the product of the stroke-width and the stroke-dashoffset rather than the dashoffset alone.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
This can be reproduced by simply editing the stroke-width and stroke-dashoffset tags.  The following pairs of values are equivalent in terms of dashoffset appearance:

stroke-width, stroke-dashoffset
1, 4
4, 1
2, 2

Actual Results:  
The width of the lines change, but the dashoffset will not change in terms of appearence.

Expected Results:  
The line should have moved forward in the stroke-dasharray and the lines should have gotten thicker (depending on the values).

We probably need to think about this a little, I'll add it to my todo list. Ping me on IRC and we'll discuss it, I'm not yet entirely sure what the right thing to do is. I think for Moz2D it makes sense to have the width and dash length related but I could be persuaded to think differently, than all we need to do is make the Moz2D backends behave consistently and at another layer deal with adjusting the dash length.
